turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Indonesian mosques.
turn.1: What are the characteristics of Indonesian mosques?
turn.2: Other characteristics are the employment of stilts in some mosques, a separate roof on the mihrab, the peaks of the roof are decorated with finials called "pataka" (the "mustoko/memolo" of Demak Sultanates) made of Borneo ironwood, ornaments on the corner of the roofs called "jamang", and fences within the perimeter of the mosque area called "kandang rasi".
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Other differences with the mosques of Java is that the Banjarese mosques contain no "serambi" (roofed porch), a traditional feature in Javanese mosques.
turn.6: Banjar-style mosques can be found in Banjarmasin and Pontianak.
turn.8: The mosque "Masjid Tinggi" in Bagan Serai, Malaysia, is a Banjar-style mosque.
turn.10: Mosques in Sulawesi follows the architectural style of Javanese mosque with multiple (usually three) tiered roofs.
turn.11: Is there anything else you can share about the article?
turn.12: Islam came to Maluku in the late 15th century via Java, with the strongest impact was felt in the spice islands of Ternate and Tidore.
